Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Geometrical and Statistical Modeling of Space-Time symmetries for Human Action Analysis and Retraining

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary research aims to advance current understanding and utilization of space-time symmetries in analyzing human movements, using fundamental tools from engineering, geometry, and statistics. Broader applications of this research include home or workplace-based self-reflection of daily activities, promotion of higher efficiency of human movements, and long-term management and/or prevention of movement disorders. While the need for comprehensively and statistically analyzing human kinematics is well chronicled, the current measures are often limited to simplistic quantities such as speeds and acceleration profiles of individual limbs. This project will focus on both spatial and temporal symmetries of limb movements, full body shapes, and complete dynamical actions, for assessment of movements ranging from daily activities to physiotherapeutic exercises.

Symmetry has been used in the past, in clinical biomechanics, but in a limited way. This project will develop a comprehensive theory, built on fundamental tools from differential geometry and statistical analysis of geometric objects, to represent, quantify, analyze, and classify motions according to their level of symmetry. The specific forms of symmetry will include spatial reflection, temporal reflection, and space-time glide symmetries. This formulation will incorporate data from various sensing modalities and features, including point trajectories and stick figures from motion capture systems, to shape silhouettes and dynamic textures obtained from video sensors. The project outcomes also include the development of a real-time media-system for movement re-training and reflection of common actions, such as sitting to standing (STS). The proposal brings together a strong and inter-disciplinary team of researchers with expertise in computer vision and action recognition (Turaga), differential geometry and statistics (Srivastava), and somatics and kinesiology (Coleman).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was an interdisciplinary collaboration between Arizona State University and Florida State University, aimed at developing new fundamental methods for representing time-series data, that takes into account the full richness of the available data. The key idea in our approach is to view observed time-series as a composition of an underlyign signal with a temporal diffeomorphism, as a means to model the variability associated in observed time-series. This model of time-series works especially well for human-movement data, since human movement is intrinsically a dynamical process, that exhibits rate variations due to various physical and biomechanical reasons. The specific application areas we developed were in analysis of human movement data, from devices such as wearbales, motion-capture devices, and more, in a manner that throws light on symmetry-related properties of the movement. We developed new techniques, algorithms, and systems that leveraged mathematical developments in elastic time-series analysis and function-space methods.

 

In terms of applications, symmetry in human movement lies at the foundation of many ways to model and correlate movement to health-related outcomes. Symmetry in human movement manifests itself in a variety of ways, including spatial symmetry, temporal symmetry, and spatio-temporal reflection symmetry. Our outcomes results in a various algorithm to compute from real sensor data, all these different measures of symmetry, as applied to actions of daily living such as walking, picking up objects from the ground, and standing up sitting down from a chair. The choice of these actions is motivated by their ubiquity in daily lives, and the enormous impact our systems can have on helping the general populace be more aware of habitual inefficiences in their movements.

 

Our project resulted in several publications, reports, demonstrations, presentations, and talks in various venues of both theoretical and applied interest, including venues interested in mathematics, statistics, geometry, computer vision, health and wellness. We have increased our network of collaborations to several health professionals who are now beginning to use our methods to data of real clinical relevance.
